title: Developing a Robust Business Strategy
headline: Master the essentials of formulating and implementing a winning business strategy in this free online course.
description: The success of a business is evaluated based on its ability to meet set goals and objectives. Developing and implementing a viable strategy is therefore central to achieving organisational goals and is a precursor for business success, regardless of the size or industry. This course will discuss the basics of strategic management, including strategic frameworks and considerations for creating and executing a winning strategy for business.

courseDescription:
To achieve organisational goals, corporations require road maps to correct their course when the need arises. A business' strategy provides such a road map. While we often use 'business strategy' and 'strategic planning' as buzzwords, there is vast conceptual and applicable knowledge to help managers formulate and implement these procedures and achieve organisational goals while keeping competition at bay. This course aims to provide you with this knowledge, beginning with a deep dive into strategy as a concept.

In its first half, the course will introduce the business of strategic planning and reveal the evolution of strategy over time. Here, you will also learn the importance of this in a business model and the key approaches to strategy management like 'game theory' and 'design thinking’. Additionally, you will understand some concepts like ‘corporate social responsibility’ and ‘digital disruption’, which are vital topics to consider when creating a business strategy that will remain solid regardless of tensions and unforeseen occurrences.

Finally, we will go over the process of creating systems and more critical considerations for the strategic planning process. Here, you will learn about essential success factors, evaluate a company's capabilities and identify core competencies to develop a strategy. We will reveal some proven techniques for competitive markets, globalisation and commerce's future. By the end of this course, you will have a profound understanding of business strategy and how to formulate and implement winning methods for organisations great and small. Enrol today!

Start Course Now

All Alison courses are free to enrol study and complete. To successfully complete this certificate course and become an Alison Graduate, you need to achieve 80% or higher in each course assessment. Once you have completed this certificate course, you have the option to acquire an official Diploma, which is a great way to share your achievement with the world.

Your Alison certificate is:
  • Ideal for sharing with potential employers
  • Include it in your CV, professional social media profiles and job applications.
  • An indication of your commitment to continuously learn, upskill & achieve high results.
  • An incentive for you to continue empowering yourself through lifelong learning.
Alison offers 3 types of Diplomas for completed Diploma courses:
  • Digital certificate: a downloadable certificate in PDF format immediately available to you when you complete your purchase.
  • certificate: a physical version of your officially branded and security-marked certificate, posted to you with FREE shipping.
  • Framed certificate: a physical version of your officially branded and security marked certificate in a stylish frame, posted to you with FREE shipping.
Start Course Now

All certificate are available to purchase through the Alison Shop. For more information on purchasing Alison certificate, please visit our FAQs. If you decide not to purchase your Alison certificate, you can still demonstrate your achievement by sharing your Learner Record or Learner Achievement Verification, both of which are accessible from your Dashboard. For more details on our certificate pricing, please visit our Pricing Page

modules.name: Module
modules.description: This module will introduce you to the concept of strategic management and expose you to strategic models. You will learn about the evolution of strategic management, and its relationship with business models. Also, you will learn about Game Theory, design thinking and other approaches to strategic thinking.
topics: Strategy Models and Approaches – Learning Outcomes
Strategy Models and Approaches – Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.description: In this module, you will be introduced to the process involved in formulating and executing a successful strategy for an organisation. You will learn to apply the five forces framework in evaluating a business and formulating a strategy for it accordingly. You will also learn to develop strategies for international expansion and new commerce.
topics: Developing and Executing a Strategy – Learning Outcomes
Building a Strategy for the Future
Developing and Executing a Strategy – Lesson Summary

topics: Developing a Robust Business Strategy – Course assessment

slides:
• Learning Outcomes

  • On the successful completion of this module, you'll be able to;
    • Define strategy
    • Summarise the evolution of strategic planning and management.
    • Identify some key approaches to strategic management.
    • Distinguish between strategic thinking and design-led thinking.
    • Explain the importance of Corporate Social Responsibility.

  • Lesson Summary

    • Strategy is a method or plan chosen to bring about a desired future, such as the achievement of a goal or solution to a problem.
    • A business model is a roadmap to how a firm conducts its business and acts as a link between strategy and the creation of value.
    • Strategic management is primarily about empowering functional management with the skills and knowledge for strategic thinking.
    • In its early days, strategy was primarily tied to the management of budgets. Common models for strategic management include the 3C model, triple bottom line and EVR congruence model.
    • There are three hierarchies of strategy, corporate, business and functional level strategy. Prescriptive and emergent approaches are the key approaches to strategy.
    • Game theory uses probability, choice, human behaviour and gamified scenarios to support decision making. Popular game theory scenarios include the Monty Hall problem and the prisoner’s dilemma
    • The rational decision-making model suggests that decision making follows six methodical steps. Bounded rationality affirms that decisions are bounded by the ability of the decision-maker.
    • Corporate Social Responsibility insists that firms become more accountable to the communities they service.

  • Learning Outcomes

  • On the successful completion of this module, you will be able to;
    • Summarise Porter's five forces framework.
    • Define Critical Success Factors.
    • Identify some generic competitive strategies.
    • Explain vertical and horizontal integration.
    • Evaluate strategic approaches to international expansion.
    • Outline the core skills required for strategic thinking.

  • Functional Level Strategy

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Lesson Summary

    • The five forces framework considers the influence of the players in a competitive environment. Porter’s five forces include threat of new entry, competitive rivalry, supplier power, threat of substitutes and buyer power.
    • Competitive group analysis identifies and visually represents competitive forces. The balanced scorecard has 4 perspectives; internal, customer, financial and learning and growth analysis.
    • Total Quality Management and Six Sigma are tools used to ensure a firm adopts and sustains best practices.
    • The five generic competitive strategies include low-cost provider, broad differentiation, focused low-cost, focused differentiation and best-cost provider strategies.
    •  Vertical integration involves controlling the company’s complete value chain.
    • Outsourcing allows a company to concentrate on mission-critical activities. Related diversification involves diversifying into a business with value chain synergy and strategic fit.
    • Essential practices for functional-level planning include detail, strategic alignment, measuring performance, assigning resources and integration.
    • Reasons for international expansion include; gaining new customers, achieving economies of scale, access to low-cost inputs, exploiting core competencies and gaining access to foreign resources
    • Options for international expansion include export, licensing, franchising, strategic alliance and wholly-owned subsidiary.
